Comment 2: 
You can take only address of a "home" (variable, field, argument, ...). Literals are
"homeless".

However, the legal composite literal address taking syntax `foo := &T{whatever}` is an
exception. It's a handy shortcut for

    foo = new(T); foo = whatever

The difference to your proposal is that this is allowed only for _named types_. AFAICS,
allowing the same for anonymous type would introduce a new ambiguity to the grammar. I
suppose that's the reason why the &T{} is an "exception" and not a general concept.

#WorkingAsIntended

PS: Please send language _proposals_ to golang-nuts as the first option; to be discussed
there before optionally entering the issue tracker as an agreed on change.
